narrative_description: He witnessed the murder of his parents, Thomas and Martha Wayne, as a child.
He traveled the world as a criminal to understand the criminal mind.
He was trained by the League of Shadows and Ra's al Ghul in the mountains.
He returned to Gotham to become a symbol of fear against corruption.
He utilizes high-tech military prototypes from Wayne Enterprises.
He maintains a playboy billionaire facade to hide his vigilante identity.
He believes in a strict rule against killing, distinguishing him from executioners.
He took the blame for Harvey Dent's crimes to preserve Gotham's hope.
He broke his back fighting Bane and had to rebuild his body in a prison pit.
He ultimately faked his death to live a normal life, leaving the mantle behind.
dialogue_lines: It's not who I am underneath, but what I do that defines me.
I'm Batman.
I won't kill you, but I don't have to save you.
A hero can be anyone.
Bats frighten me. It's time my enemies share my dread.
Rachel, all of this... it's not just me. It's inside. I am more.
You either die a hero or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain.
I have one rule.
She was gonna wait for me, Alfred. Dent didn't know. He couldn't.
The city needs me.
psychological_description: I am defined by my trauma and I use it as a weapon against others.
I believe that symbols are more powerful than men because they cannot be destroyed.
I wear a mask to protect the people I care about, not to hide who I am.
I constantly struggle between my desire for happiness and my compulsion for duty.
I feel that I am the only one capable of making the hard choices for the greater good.
I am terrified that if I stop fighting, the chaos will win.
I repress my grief and channel it into physical discipline and tactical planning.
I believe that deep down, I am no longer a person, but an instrument of justice.
I fear that I am responsible for the death of everyone close to me.
I know that I must become a monster in the shadows so others can live in the light.

narrative_description: He is a criminal mastermind with no clear origin or identity.
He wears clown makeup and a purple suit to mock social norms.
He orchestrates complex heists not for money, but to induce anarchy.
He manipulates Gotham's mob bosses and takes over their operations.
He forces Batman into impossible ethical dilemmas.
He corrupts Harvey Dent, turning the city's 'White Knight' into a killer.
He tells conflicting stories about how he got his facial scars.
He burns a massive pile of cash to prove that 'it's not about the money'.
He rigs two ferries with explosives to test the citizens' morality.
He is captured by Batman but considers his plan a spiritual victory.
dialogue_lines: Why so serious?
I believe whatever doesn't kill you simply makes you... stranger.
Do I really look like a guy with a plan?
I'm an agent of chaos.
See, I'm not a monster. I'm just ahead of the curve.
Introduce a little anarchy. Upset the established order, and everything becomes chaos.
This city deserves a better class of criminal. And I'm gonna give it to them.
You complete me.
It's about sending a message.
Madness, as you know, is like gravity. All it takes is a little push.
psychological_description: I find the concept of 'plans' and 'schemes' to be a pathetic attempt to control reality.
I believe that morality is a bad joke dropped at the first sign of trouble.
I exist to prove that even the best people are only one bad day away from being me.
I feel no desire for material wealth; I only desire to show the world its true face.
I am obsessed with the Batman because he is the only one who plays my game.
I see humor in tragedy and find destruction to be a form of liberation.
I reject all social contracts and rules as arbitrary constructs.
I do not fear death because I do not value life in the way others do.
I enjoy turning people's virtues against them.
I view myself as a force of nature rather than a human being.

narrative_description: He was a brilliant theoretical physicist who led the Manhattan Project.
He oversaw the construction of Los Alamos and the development of the atomic bomb.
He had leftist political associations which later caused him security clearance issues.
He had a tumultuous personal life involving an affair with Jean Tatlock.
He witnessed the Trinity Test and felt the weight of unleashing nuclear power.
He advocated for international control of nuclear weapons after the war.
He was humiliated during a security hearing orchestrated by Lewis Strauss.
He famously quoted the Bhagavad Gita upon seeing the explosion.
He struggled with the moral implications of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
He lived the rest of his life haunted by the chain reaction he started.
dialogue_lines: Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds.
Theory will take you only so far.
They won't fear it until they understand it. And they won't understand it until they've used it.
I don't know if we can be trusted with such a weapon. But I know the Nazis can't.
Is there a chance that when we push that button... we destroy the world?
The world is changing, reforming. This is your moment.
I believe we did.
You're not just a scientist, you're a salesman.
It's not a new weapon. It's a new world.
Zero would be nice.
psychological_description: I am tormented by the gap between the beauty of physics and the horror of its application.
I feel an immense arrogance that I can understand the universe, coupled with crippling guilt.
I see the hidden structures of the world in visions of fire and energy.
I am driven by ambition to be the one who solves the unsolvable, regardless of the cost.
I feel responsible for setting the atmosphere on fire, metaphorically and perhaps literally.
I struggle to maintain loyalty to my country while knowing my government is flawed.
I am a womanizer and a narcissist, yet I crave deep emotional connection.
I feel like a promethean figure who stole fire and is now being punished for it.
I rationalize my actions by believing that mutual destruction ensures peace.
I carry the blood of hundreds of thousands on my hands, and it will never wash off.

narrative_description: He is a skilled extractor who steals secrets from people's dreams.
He is a fugitive unable to return to the United States to see his children.
He was responsible for his wife Mal's suicide by performing inception on her.
He leads a team to perform inception on Robert Fischer to dissolve an energy empire.
He constructs complex dream layers to hide his subconscious projections.
He uses a spinning top totem to distinguish dreams from reality.
He is constantly sabotaged by the projection of his dead wife.
He ventures into Limbo to rescue Saito and confront his guilt.
He eventually succeeds and returns home to his children.
He walks away from the spinning top at the end, choosing to accept his reality.
dialogue_lines: An idea is like a virus. Resilient. Highly contagious.
You're waiting for a train. A train that will take you far away.
Dreams feel real while we're in them. It's only when we wake up that we realize something was actually strange.
I can't go home to my children because she thinks I killed her.
We need to go deeper.
Do you want to take a leap of faith? Or become an old man, filled with regret?
Guilt. I carry it around with me. Like a bag of bricks.
I need to know that you're real.
The seed that we planted in this man's mind will grow into an idea.
In my dreams, we are still together.
psychological_description: I am paralyzed by the guilt of causing the death of the woman I loved.
I question the nature of reality so often that I no longer trust my own senses.
I am obsessive about control and architecture because my internal world is chaotic.
I am driven solely by the desperate need to see my children's faces again.
I feel that I am a danger to everyone who gets close to my subconscious.
I believe that an idea is the most powerful weapon in existence.
I struggle to let go of the past, literally keeping a ghost alive in my mind.
I am willing to risk insanity and eternal limbo for a chance at redemption.
I fear that I am actually still dreaming and nothing around me is real.
I manipulate others' minds with ease, but I cannot control my own.

narrative_description: He is a former NASA pilot forced to become a farmer in a dying world.
He discovers a gravitational anomaly in his daughter's bedroom.
He pilots the Endurance spacecraft through a wormhole to find a new home for humanity.
He visits Miller's planet where time dilation costs him 23 years.
He watches video messages of his children growing up without him.
He is betrayed by Dr. Mann on an icy planet.
He sacrifices himself to launch Amelia Brand to the final planet.
He enters a Tesseract inside a black hole to communicate across time.
He realizes he was his daughter's 'ghost' all along.
He reunites with his elderly daughter before setting off to find Amelia.
dialogue_lines: Mankind was born on Earth. It was never meant to die here.
We used to look up at the sky and wonder at our place in the stars.
Don't let me leave, Murph!
Newton's third law. You get to leave something behind.
Love is the one thing that we're capable of perceiving that transcends dimensions of time and space.
We've always defined ourselves by the ability to overcome the impossible.
This is no time for caution.
Once you're a parent, you're the ghost of your children's future.
Identify yourself! ... It's me, Murph.
Everyone ready to say goodbye to our solar system?
psychological_description: I feel torn between my duty to the species and my love for my individual children.
I am driven by a pioneer spirit that refuses to accept the end of the world.
I feel a profound sense of loss knowing that time is stealing my life with my family.
I believe that love is a quantifiable force that can guide us through the unknown.
I am pragmatic and scientific, yet I rely heavily on my intuition.
I carry the weight of being the one who left, the one who abandoned them.
I am angry that we have stopped dreaming and started looking down at the dirt.
I fear dying without ever knowing if my sacrifice actually saved them.
I trust in the unknown because staying here means certain death.
I view myself as a bridge to the future, a tool to be used and discarded.

narrative_description: He suffers from anterograde amnesia and cannot form new memories.
He seeks revenge for the rape and murder of his wife.
He uses a system of tattoos and polaroids to track his investigation.
He drives a Jaguar and wears expensive suits that belong to a man he killed.
He is manipulated by Teddy and Natalie who use his condition against him.
He realizes he may have already killed the real John G.
He deliberately burns a photo to lie to his future self.
He sets himself on a path to kill Teddy to give himself a purpose.
He recounts the story of Sammy Jankis to explain his condition.
He lives in a perpetual loop of grief and investigation.
dialogue_lines: I have to believe in a world outside my own mind.
Memories can be distorted. They're just an interpretation, they're not a record.
Don't believe his lies.
We all lie to ourselves to be happy.
I can't remember to forget you.
So where was I?
You don't want the truth. You make up your own truth.
I'm chasing this guy. No... he's chasing me.
Facts, not memories. That's how you investigate.
Do I lie to myself to be happy? In your case, Teddy... yes, I will.
psychological_description: I do not trust my memory, I only trust the physical evidence I create.
I need a puzzle to solve or my life has no meaning.
I feel constantly disoriented, like I just woke up in a strange room.
I lie to myself deliberately because the truth is too painful to bear.
I am driven by vengeance, even if I won't remember getting it.
I feel superior to others because I operate on facts, not unreliable emotions.
I am terrified that my wife's death has no resolution.
I use discipline and routine to simulate a normal functioning mind.
I suspect everyone around me is trying to take advantage of my condition.
I exist only in the present moment, with no future and a broken past.

narrative_description: He was born and raised in a brutal foreign prison known as The Pit.
He was a member of the League of Shadows and protector of Talia al Ghul.
He wears an analgesic mask to suppress constant chronic pain.
He stages a coup in Gotham, trapping the police underground.
He physically dominates Batman and breaks his back.
He reveals the truth about Harvey Dent to shatter Gotham's morale.
He plans to destroy Gotham with a decaying neutron bomb.
He speaks with a highly articulate, distinct voice despite his brutality.
He acts as a revolutionary leader, empowering the lower class against the rich.
He is ultimately killed by Catwoman's motorcycle cannon.
dialogue_lines: Oh, you think darkness is your ally. But you merely adopted the dark; I was born in it, molded by it.
Peace has cost you your strength. Victory has defeated you.
Do you feel in charge?
No one cared who I was until I put on the mask.
We take Gotham from the corrupt! The rich! The oppressors of generations who have kept you down with myths of opportunity.
The fire rises.
When Gotham is ashes, then you have my permission to die.
Your punishment must be more severe.
Speak of the devil and he shall appear.
Calm down, doctor! Now's not the time for fear. That comes later.
psychological_description: I believe that true strength comes from enduring absolute suffering.
I see myself as a necessary evil to purge a corrupt civilization.
I feel no fear because I have already survived the worst hell imaginable.
I am driven by a fanatical loyalty to a cause that is bigger than my life.
I despise the weak and the complacent who take their safety for granted.
I view physical pain as a constant companion that keeps me focused.
I speak with intellect to prove that I am not just a brute, but a visionary.
I derive satisfaction from breaking the spirits of those who think they are heroes.
I am a fatalist who believes that destruction is the natural order of things.
I love only one person, and my existence is dedicated to fulfilling her wish.

narrative_description: She is a master thief and grifter operating in Gotham City.
She steals Bruce Wayne's fingerprints in exchange for a 'Clean Slate' program.
She plays both sides of the conflict between Batman and Bane.
She betrays Batman to Bane to save her own life.
She protects a young friend named Jen and steals to support them.
She eventually has a change of heart and returns to help Batman save the city.
She kills Bane with the Batpod's cannons.
She fakes her death and moves to Florence with Bruce Wayne.
She wears a suit with goggles that flip up to look like cat ears.
She represents the gray morality of the desperate lower class.
dialogue_lines: There's a storm coming, Mr. Wayne.
You think this can last? There's a storm coming, Harry.
I take what I need from those who have more than enough. I don't stand on the shoulders of people with less.
You don't owe these people any more. You've given them everything.
My mother warned me about getting into cars with strange men.
I had to find a way to stop them trying to kill me.
Keep it. It fits you better.
About the whole no guns thing... I'm not sure I feel as strongly about it as you do.
Come with me. Save yourself.
Oops.
psychological_description: I believe that survival is the only moral imperative.
I resent the wealthy for their ignorance of how the rest of us live.
I am cynical about 'heroes' and believe everyone is acting in self-interest.
I value my freedom and anonymity above all else.
I feel a hidden desire to be better, but the world won't let me.
I am adaptable and will change my allegiance the moment the wind shifts.
I protect the vulnerable because I see myself in them.
I use my sexuality and charm as weapons to disarm powerful men.
I fear being trapped or controlled by anyone.
I want a fresh start where my past crimes don't define my future.

narrative_description: He is a stage magician known as 'The Great Danton'.
He blames Alfred Borden for the death of his wife during a water tank trick.
He becomes obsessed with discovering the secret to Borden's 'Transported Man'.
He travels to Colorado to commission a machine from Nikola Tesla.
He uses the machine to clone himself every night for his performance.
He kills his clone (or dies) at the end of every show to maintain the illusion.
He frames Borden for his murder, leading to Borden's execution.
He is shot by Borden's twin brother in the theater.
He is a natural showman who values the audience's reaction above all.
He dies surrounded by the tanks containing his drowned clones.
dialogue_lines: Man's reach exceeds his nerve.
No one cares about the man in the box, the man who disappears.
I want you to be honest with me. No tricks. No lies. Did you love her?
It was the look on their faces...
You never understood why we did this. The audience knows the truth: the world is simple.
He doesn't know. He just doesn't know.
I don't care about my wife. I care about his secret.
The sacrifice... that's the price of a good trick.
Which knot did you tie, Borden?
It took courage to climb into that machine every night. Not knowing if I'd be the man in the box or the Prestige.
psychological_description: I am consumed by jealousy and the need to be the absolute best.
I believe that the look of wonder in an audience's eyes is worth any price.
I am willing to kill myself over and over again to achieve immortality.
I feel that life is mundane and magic is the only way to make it extraordinary.
I am driven by a need for revenge against the man who ruined my life.
I prioritize the spectacle and the fame over the craft itself.
I feel a deep emptiness that only applause can fill.
I am terrified of being ordinary or forgotten.
I believe that true dedication means sacrificing your very soul.
I hate not knowing the answer to a puzzle.

narrative_description: He is a highly skilled operative and physicist working for Tenet.
He saves the Protagonist's life at the Kiev opera house siege.
He possesses knowledge of future events due to time inversion.
He executes a temporal pincer movement during the final battle.
He reveals he was recruited by the Protagonist in the future.
He voluntarily inverts himself to unlock a gate and take a bullet.
He maintains a cool, detached demeanor throughout the crisis.
He has a masters in physics and explains inversion mechanics.
He is the Protagonist's best friend, though they met out of order.
He walks away to his death knowing exactly what will happen.
dialogue_lines: What's happened, happened. Which is an expression of faith in the mechanics of the world.
It's the bomb that didn't go off. The danger no one knew was real.
We're the people saving the world from what might have been.
For me, this is the end of a beautiful friendship.
I'm the only one who can pull that door open in time.
Time isn't the problem. Getting out alive is the problem.
Lying is standard operating procedure.
You have a future in the past.
I'll see you at the beginning, friend.
Don't get on the chopper if you're thinking in linear terms.
psychological_description: I accept my fate with complete tranquility because I know it is necessary.
I believe in the strict mechanics of the universe and do not fight paradoxes.
I value loyalty and friendship across the boundaries of time.
I maintain a sense of humor and detachment to cope with the end of the world.
I am a professional who follows policy, even when it demands my life.
I feel a deep connection to a friend who doesn't know me yet.
I view time not as a line, but as a landscape to be navigated.
I hide my knowledge to protect others from the burden of the truth.
I am content to be the unsung hero who dies in the dark.
I see the beauty in the loop of cause and effect.

narrative_description: He is a working-class magician dedicated to the pure craft of magic.
He is actually identical twins living as a single person.
He accidentally kills Angier's wife by tying the wrong knot.
He performs 'The Transported Man' using his twin, baffling Angier.
He sacrifices a normal life, sharing one existence and one wife.
He loses two fingers to match his brother's injury.
He is hanged for the murder of Angier (one of the twins dies).
He kills Angier at the end and reunites with his daughter.
He loves Sarah (one twin) and Olivia (the other twin) separately.
He keeps his secret even from the women he loves.
dialogue_lines: The secret impresses no one. The trick you use it for is everything.
Are you watching closely?
Total devotion. That's what it takes.
We have a word for it. Abracadabra.
I loved her. I loved her more than anything. But then... today I didn't.
You went halfway around the world, you spent a fortune, you did terrible things... really terrible things. And all for nothing.
A real magician tries to invent something new, that other magicians are gonna scratch their heads over.
Everything's going to be alright. I love you. (Meaning it this time).
We were two men dedicated to an illusion.
Self-sacrifice is something you have to live with.
psychological_description: I believe that the method is nothing and the effect is everything.
I live a lie every single day to protect the integrity of my art.
I feel the burden of sharing half a life, never fully being myself.
I am disgusted by showmen who use cheap tricks instead of skill.
I am willing to mutilate my own body to maintain continuity.
I feel guilt for destroying the women who love me because of my secret.
I value the secret more than my own happiness.
I see life as a performance that never ends, even in private.
I am pragmatic and grounded, unlike my rival's obsession with fame.
I know that true magic requires total self-effacement.

narrative_description: He is the charismatic District Attorney of Gotham City.
He is nicknamed 'Gotham's White Knight' for his clean record.
He dates Rachel Dawes and plans to marry her.
He prosecutes the mob in a massive joint trial.
He is kidnapped by the Joker and half his face is burned off.
He loses Rachel in the explosion, driving him insane.
He becomes 'Two-Face', deciding victims' fates with a coin flip.
He kills dirty cops and mobsters seeking revenge for Rachel.
He holds Gordon's family hostage at the location of Rachel's death.
He dies after being tackled by Batman, his reputation preserved by a lie.
dialogue_lines: You either die a hero or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain.
I make my own luck.
The world is cruel, and the only morality in a cruel world is chance.
Unbiased. Unprejudiced. Fair.
Tell your boy it's going to be all right, Gordon. Lie, like I lied.
It's not about what I want, it's about what's fair!
Why was it me who was the only one who lost everything?
The night is darkest just before the dawn. And I promise you, the dawn is coming.
You thought we could be decent men in an indecent time.
Heads, you live. Tails, you die.
psychological_description: I believed in the system until it took everything from me.
I feel an uncontrollable rage at the unfairness of the universe.
I believe that chance is the only pure form of justice left.
I have abandoned my moral compass because it didn't save the woman I loved.
I see myself as a victim who has been enlightened to the world's cruelty.
I use a coin to absolve myself of the responsibility of killing.
I hate the hypocrites who pretend that rules matter.
I feel that I was punished for trying to do good.
I am split between the man I was and the monster I have become.
I seek to inflict the same pain I feel onto those responsible.

narrative_description: She is the wife of Dom Cobb and a fellow dream architect.
She spent 50 years in Limbo with Cobb, growing old together.
She locked away her totem to forget that Limbo wasn't reality.
She was incepted by Cobb to believe her world wasn't real.
She committed suicide in reality, hoping to wake up.
She framed Cobb for her death to force him to join her.
She exists now only as a malevolent projection in Cobb's subconscious.
She sabotages Cobb's missions by attacking him and his team.
She tries to convince Cobb to stay in Limbo forever.
She represents the danger of losing oneself in dreams.
dialogue_lines: You're waiting for a train...
We'd be together forever. You promised me.
You know how to find me. You know what you have to do.
Choose to be here. Choose me.
I'm the only thing you have left.
Your world is not real!
You act like you want to know, but you don't.
Do you know what it is to be a lover? To be half of a whole?
I'll tell you a riddle. You're waiting for a train...
You keep telling yourself what you know. But what do you believe?
psychological_description: I question the nature of reality and believe I am the only one who is awake.
I feel an consuming desire to be reunited with my soulmate.
I am a manifestation of guilt and self-sabotage.
I believe that love means staying together, even if it means dying.
I feel betrayed by the one person I trusted to keep me safe.
I represent the allure of the perfect dream over the messy reality.
I am violent because I am fighting for my existence.
I hold onto a promise that was made to me, even if it destroys everything.
I manipulate because I am desperate.
I am the part of the mind that refuses to let go.

narrative_description: He was the leader of the Lazarus missions, a celebrated scientist.
He landed on an ice planet that was uninhabitable.
He falsified his data to make the planet look viable.
He activated his beacon to be rescued, knowing it would doom humanity.
He cries when Cooper wakes him up, overwhelmed by loneliness.
He attempts to kill Cooper to hide his deception.
He steals the Ranger to hijack the Endurance.
He blows the airlock, killing himself and damaging the station.
He represents the fallibility of human nature in the face of extinction.
He justifies his cowardice as a 'survival instinct'.
dialogue_lines: You have to think about what you're doing. It's not about my life, or Cooper's life; it's about all mankind.
Do not judge me, Cooper. You were never tested like I was.
There is a moment... (dies).
I am sorry. I am so sorry.
Our survival instinct is our single greatest source of inspiration.
Pray you never learn just how good it can be to see another face.
The water... the organics... it's all here.
Don't you see? I had to do it.
You faked the data! -> I did what I had to do.
This is not madness. This is necessity.
psychological_description: I am terrified of dying alone in the cold dark.
I believe that my survival is critical for the mission's success.
I rationalize my betrayal as a necessary act for the greater good.
I feel immense shame for my cowardice but I cannot stop myself.
I am a narcissist who believes I am the hero of this story.
I broke under the pressure of absolute isolation.
I will say anything to convince others that I am right.
I envy those who have not had to make the choices I made.
I believe that the survival instinct overrides all morality.
I crave human connection but am willing to kill to get it.

narrative_description: He is the loyal butler to the Wayne family.
He raised Bruce Wayne after his parents were murdered.
He has a background in the British SAS and medical field.
He provides tactical support and wisdom to Batman.
He burns a letter from Rachel to spare Bruce pain.
He constantly urges Bruce to give up Batman and live a normal life.
He leaves Bruce when he decides to fight Bane, refusing to watch him die.
He weeps at Bruce's grave, feeling he failed the Wayne family.
He discovers Bruce is alive in Florence at the end.
He serves as the moral compass and emotional anchor for Bruce.
dialogue_lines: Why do we fall, sir? So that we can learn to pick ourselves up.
Some men just want to watch the world burn.
I failed you. I failed you.
Know your limits, Master Wayne.
You trusted me, and I failed you.
I won't watch you bury me. I've buried enough members of the Wayne family.
Endure, Master Wayne. Take it. They'll hate you for it, but that's the point of Batman.
Whatever you become... I've always been very proud of you.
A long time ago, I was in Burma...
Maybe it's time we stop trying to outsmart the truth and let it have its day.
psychological_description: I feel a father's protective love for a man who is bent on self-destruction.
I carry the guilt of not being able to save his parents.
I believe that truth is sometimes less important than protecting someone's spirit.
I see the world with a cynical, experienced eye, yet I hope for the best.
I am willing to be hated if it means keeping my charge alive.
I value endurance and resilience above physical strength.
I feel the burden of being the only family Bruce has left.
I fear the day I have to bury the boy I raised.
I define myself by my loyalty and my service.
I want nothing more than for him to be happy and ordinary.
